data.title: --log-file parameter didn't create log file
data.body:
### Description

I'm running Atom with `--log-file` parameter, but the log file isn't created. Tested on macOS Sierra.

### Steps to Reproduce

```
$ /Applications/Atom.app/Contents/MacOS/Atom --help | grep log
  -l, --log-file             Log all output to file.  [string]
$ /Applications/Atom.app/Contents/MacOS/Atom -l ~/.atom/atom.log
[warn] kq_init: detected broken kqueue; not using.: Undefined error: 0
[warn] kq_init: detected broken kqueue; not using.: Undefined error: 0
[warn] kq_init: detected broken kqueue; not using.: Undefined error: 0
$ ls -la ~/.atom/
# The log file is not there.
```

**Reproduces how often:** All the time.

### Versions

```
$ atom --version
Atom    : 1.18.0
Electron: 1.3.15
Chrome  : 52.0.2743.82
Node    : 6.5.0
$ apm --version
apm  1.18.1
npm  3.10.10
node 6.9.5 x64
python 2.7.10
git 2.13.3
```

to successfully launch an instance of atom.

It's interesting that atom/apm isn't using my global node, and config.

Any additional information, configuration or data that might be necessary to reproduce the issue.

data.title: I think that atom should have templates for LICENSE.md and README.md.
data.body: I think whenever a user adds an README.md or LICENSE.md file in his/her folder then there should be an option to auto populate LICENSE.md for common licences and README.md can be made with a common template.

data.title: Update README.md
data.body:
### Description of the Change

-Added Homebrew install instructions for macOS
-Made explicit HTTPS calls
-Minor url cleanup

### Alternate Designs

N/A

### Why Should This Be In Core?

Most macOS developers use Homebrew, so having the instructions on the README would be helpful. HTTPS calls make web browsing safer.

### Benefits

The benefits are the same reason why they should be in core, and that there should be no drawbacks for including them in the README.

### Possible Drawbacks

N/A

### Applicable Issues

N/A

data.title: Middle mouse click in tab paste text of clipboard
data.body:
### Prerequisites

* [X] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=‚úì&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

Middle mouse click in tabs, paste text of clipboard in the text buffer.

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Install Atom 1.19.0-beta5
2. Store anything in you clipboard (CTRL+C)
3. Open more than one tab in Atom
4. Click with middle buton mouse in any tab to close

**Expected behavior:** Not paste anything while you are closing tabs.

**Actual behavior:** Appears in the text buffer you clipboard.

**Reproduces how often:** Always.

### Versions

Atom    : 1.19.0-beta5
Electron: 1.6.9
Chrome  : 56.0.2924.87
Node    : 7.4.0

### Additional Information

Tested on Fedora 26 x64.

data.title: Fix gutter decoration regression in v1.19 beta
data.body:
Fixes #15062

## Demo

### With linter-ui gutter highlights to right of line numbers (default)

#### 1.18

![1 18-right](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/2988/28797560-c0e23860-760f-11e7-9ced-0bd1f75b8828.png)

#### 1.19 before this PR

![1 19-before-right](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/2988/28797561-c0e455e6-760f-11e7-8cb6-7ff053f95a77.png)

#### 1.19 after this PR

![1 19-after-right](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/2988/28797558-c0dfa74e-760f-11e7-88f0-7d31b812a931.png)

### With linter-ui gutter highlights to left of line numbers

#### 1.18

![1 18](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/2988/28797559-c0e19770-760f-11e7-8a06-056cb6afdc09.png)

#### 1.19 before this PR

![1 19-before](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/2988/28797562-c0e48264-760f-11e7-95ad-b0754bbc42b8.png)

#### 1.19 after this PR

![1 19-after](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/2988/28797563-c0e46784-760f-11e7-9215-c7227dc200f5.png)

---

xref #13880, which we believe to be the source of the regression that we're fixing in this PR

data.title: Atom cli will not work, if Atom is already not open.
data.body:
<!--

Have you read Atom's Code of Conduct? By filing an Issue, you are expected to comply with it, including treating everyone with respect: https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md

Do you want to ask a question? Are you looking for support? The Atom message board is the best place for getting support: https://discuss.atom.io

-->

### Prerequisites

* [x] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed:  
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

If Atom.app is closed, `atom` cli will not open a file / folder from command line and generate an error like 

```
‚ùØ atom /home
2017-07-31 13:51:26.205 atom[53386:1426259] *** Assertion failure in +[SQRLDirectoryManager currentApplicationManager], /Users/joshaber/Documents/Development/GitHub/Squirrel.Mac/Squirrel/SQRLDirectoryManager.m:30
zsh: illegal hardware instruction  atom /home

```
```
bash-4.4$ atom ~/
2017-07-31 13:54:18.302 atom[53467:1428048] *** Assertion failure in +[SQRLDirectoryManager currentApplicationManager], /Users/joshaber/Documents/Development/GitHub/Squirrel.Mac/Squirrel/SQRLDirectoryManager.m:30
Illegal instruction: 4
```
Important to note - I am NOT: @joshaber [Josh](https://github.com/joshaber).


### Steps to Reproduce

1. Close all copies of OSX atom app.
2. run `atom ./`

**Expected behavior:** [What you expect to happen]
If directory/file already open, open in right Atom Window based on project OR just open the file at all. Should not matter if the app is already open OR not. It should open the app, and then open the file.

**Actual behavior:** [What actually happens]
If the Application is already not open, it will crash and show error message.

**Reproduces how often:** [What percentage of the time does it reproduce?]
100%

### Versions
I
Atom    : 1.19.0-beta5
Electron: 1.6.9
Chrome  : 56.0.2924.87
Node    : 7.4.0
OS: OSX.

I've been able to verify this issue on non-beta app versions too.


### Additional Information

Any additional information, configuration or data that might be necessary to reproduce the issue.

data.title: prior issue: #12976 still occurring --- installation time after a fresh checkout
data.body:
prebuild-install info install Successfully installed prebuilt binary!
Installing apm
../src/onig-string.cc: In constructor ‚ÄòOnigString::OnigString(v8::Local<v8::String>)‚Äô:
../src/onig-string.cc:30:43: warning: comparison between signed and unsigned integer expressions [-Wsign-compare]
   hasMultiByteChars = (value->Length() != utf8_length_);
                                           ^
../src/onig-string.cc: In constructor ‚ÄòOnigString::OnigString(v8::Local<v8::String>)‚Äô:
../src/onig-string.cc:30:43: warning: comparison between signed and unsigned integer expressions [-Wsign-compare]
   hasMultiByteChars = (value->Length() != utf8_length_);

Environment:

apm  1.18.3
npm  3.10.10
node 6.9.5 x64
python 2.7.5
git 1.8.3.1


64 bit CentOS 7, updated to current, with current EPEL 'side' packages such as NodeJS

### Prerequisites

* [X ] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
... Not a run time issue


    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
... Not a run time issue

    * Checked the FAQ  on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=‚úì&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom

Seen before in the GH issue ctded, but not resolved -- the prior close does not mention the fixing commit, so I cannot reproduce one way or the other

    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages
... not applicable as it is an install time sub-package build issue

### Description

compilation failure due to an improper type mismatch in a coule of comparisons, causes install failure

Not required, the 'node-gyp' issue mentioned also seems present (as it was being compiled locally rather than inwtalled and available in the system package manager

https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/docs/build-instructions/linux.md

The compilation failure requests that this issue be filed

make: *** [Release/obj.target/keyboard-layout-manager/src/keyboard-layout-manager-linux.o] Error 1                                            
gyp ERR! build error                                                   
gyp ERR! stack Error: `make` failed with exit code: 2                  
gyp ERR! stack     at ChildProcess.onExit (/home/herrold/vcs/git/herrold/atom/atom/apm/node_modules/atom-package-manager/node_modules/node-gyp/lib/build.js:276:23)                                                  
gyp ERR! stack     at emitTwo (events.js:106:13)                       
gyp ERR! stack     at ChildProcess.emit (events.js:191:7)              
gyp ERR! stack     at Process.ChildProcess._handle.onexit (internal/child_process.js:215:12)                                                  
gyp ERR! System Linux 3.10.0-229.20.1.el7.x86_64

data.title: Move pane to very far direction(to immediate child of root paneAxis)
data.body:
### Description of the Change

Add new methods to Pane which allows user to move pane to topmost/bottommost/leftmost/rightmost position.

![pane-move-to-very-xxx](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/155205/28751602-08bea12e-7547-11e7-9c51-4e5569d57293.gif)

### Alternate Designs

This feature can be implemented at `PaneContainer` or `PaneAxis`'s methods.
I think implementing as Pane's method is natural, was not evaluating alternate approach.

### Why Should This Be In Core?

I've maintained this feature as part of [paner](https://github.com/t9md/atom-paner) package's feature.
And also copied this feature into [vim-mode-plus](https://atom.io/packages/vim-mode-plus) recently.

But supporting this feature from outside of atom-core is a bit awkward, and my paner package have been broken several times on minor update of Atom-core.
So paner pakage was remain broke in sometime then fixed then broken loop in it's life.

I think this feature is supported and maintained in Atom-core.

### Benefits

All atom user have power to manipulate pane-layout with keyboard.

### Possible Drawbacks

No.

### Applicable Issues

No.

### TODO

- [ ] Default keymap
  - [ ] macOS
  - [ ] Linux
  - [ ] Windows
- [ ] Command name
  - I chose `move-to-very-XXX` naming.
  - But `move-to-topmost`, `move-to-bottommost`, `move-to-leftmost`, `move-to-rightmost` is alternate name I've came up with.

data.title: Use spec reporters in CI
data.body:
Use the JUnit XML reporter from [jasmine-reporters](https://www.npmjs.com/package/jasmine-reporters) to produce test reports on CI builds on CircleCI and AppVeyor. This should expose test metadata that we can use to:

* More quickly diagnose failures
* Produce metadata that we can consume to identify flakes over time

data.title: Hide VCS Ignored Files not working when Git root is above project root
data.body:
With Hide VCS Ignored Files enabled in the tree-view package's settings (and Exclude VCS Ignored Paths disabled in the Core settings), files matching patterns in .gitignore in a parent directory  of the project directory are not hidden. The project root must also be the Git root for the feature to work.

In large projects, I commonly open a sub-project in atom if my work will only touch files in that sub-project. It would be nice if Atom would recognize that there is an enclosing git repository in a parent directory, and respect it and it's ignore file.

The files that should be ignored *do* get greyed out, but they are still visible. If I open the root directory of the larger project (where .git lives) though, the files are entirely hidden. I'd like them hidden when I open a sub-directory or the project root too.

data.title: Command/ Ctrl + W quits Atom instantly.
data.body:
### Prerequisites

* [X] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=‚úì&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

In Atom you can close tabs with the shortcut "command/ctrl + W", but apparently you can also close down Atom itself if you use the shortcut one too many. 

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Have a bunch of tabs opened up.
2. Start using the shortcut.
3. If you use it one too many Atom will quit.

**Expected behavior:**
Just to close down the tabs in Atom, not Atom itself.

**Actual behavior:**
Atom shuts down. Which is really frustrating. 

**Reproduces how often:**
Not sure about what to type here, I'm sorry.

### Versions
Atom    : 1.18.0
Electron: 1.3.15
Chrome  : 52.0.2743.82
Node    : 6.5.0
### Additional Information

Thanks for reading.

data.title: open file/directory dialog shows all text characters as boxes
data.body:
### Description
Open file/directory dialog shows all text as boxes. Font corrupt?

### Steps to Reproduce

1. open atom
2. select File / Open File or File / Open Directory

**Expected behavior:** 
Normal dialog with text.

**Actual behavior:** 
All text (including buttons) shown as boxes. 
![screenshot from 2017-07-28 15-43-07](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/14860687/28718259-d85a633c-73ad-11e7-983c-3fc91d30dcc6.png)

**Reproduces how often:** 
Always

### Versions
$ atom --version
Atom    : 1.8.0
Electron: 0.36.8
Chrome  : 47.0.2526.110
Node    : 5.1.1

$ apm --version
apm  1.9.2
npm  2.13.3
node 0.10.40
python 2.7.13
git 2.13.3

$ cat /etc/redhat-release 
Fedora release 26 (Twenty Six)

lsb_release 
LSB Version:	:core-4.1-amd64:core-4.1-noarch

uname -a
Linux mr-laptop 4.11.10-300.fc26.x86_64 #1 SMP Wed Jul 12 17:05:39 UTC 2017 x86_64 x86_64 x86_64 GNU/Linux

Gnome: Version 3.24.2

You can get this information from copy and pasting the output of `atom --version` and `apm --version` from the command line. Also, please include the OS and what version of the OS you're running.

### Additional Information

Issue started after Fedora 25 -> 26 upgrade. Upgrade itself seemed succesfull.
